Title: Proof that the trace of a matrix is the sum of its eigenvalues
Content: I have looked extensively for a proof on the internet but all of them were too obscure. I would appreciate if someone could lay out a simple proof for this important result. Thank you.
AcceptedAnswer:
These answers require way too much machinery. By definition, the characteristic polynomial of an $n\times n$ matrix $A$ is given by 
$$p(t) = \det(A-tI) = (-1)^n \big(t^n - (\text{tr} A) \,t^{n-1} + \dots + (-1)^n \det A\big)\,.$$
On the other hand, $p(t) = (-1)^n(t-\lambda_1)\dots (t-\lambda_n)$, where the $\lambda_j$ are the eigenvalues of $A$. So, comparing coefficients,  we have $\text{tr}A = \lambda_1 + \dots + \lambda_n$.

proof:
Problem:
Prove that for any square matrix A defined over an algebraically closed field, the trace of A is the sum of its eigenvalues and the determinant of A is the product of its eigenvalues.

Proof:
Let A be an n×n matrix over an algebraically closed field. The characteristic polynomial of A is given by:
$$p(t) = \det(A-tI)$$
It is a standard result that the characteristic polynomial can be written in terms of the trace and determinant of the matrix:
$$p(t) = (-1)^n \big(t^n - (\text{tr} A) \,t^{n-1} + \dots + (-1)^n \det A\big)$$

The eigenvalues λ₁, λ₂, ..., λₙ of A are, by definition, the roots of the characteristic polynomial p(t). Since the matrix is defined over an algebraically closed field, the polynomial splits completely into linear factors:
$$p(t) = (-1)^n (t - λ₁)(t - λ₂)⋯(t - λₙ)$$

Expanding this factored form using Vieta's formulas gives:
$$(t - λ₁)(t - λ₂)⋯(t - λₙ) = t^n - (λ₁ + λ₂ + ⋯ + λₙ)t^{n-1} + \dots + (-1)^n(λ₁λ₂⋯λₙ)$$
Therefore, the characteristic polynomial is:
$$p(t) = (-1)^n\big[t^n - (λ₁ + λ₂ + ⋯ + λₙ)t^{n-1} + \dots + (-1)^n(λ₁λ₂⋯λₙ)\big]$$

By comparing the two expressions for p(t), we can equate the coefficients of the powers of t.

1.  Equating the coefficients of the tⁿ⁻¹ term:
    $$-(\text{tr} A) = -(λ₁ + λ₂ + ⋯ + λₙ)$$
    $$\text{tr} A = \sum_{i=1}^{n} λ_i$$

2.  Equating the constant terms (the t⁰ term):
    $$(-1)^n \det A = (-1)^n(λ₁λ₂⋯λₙ)$$
    $$\det A = \prod_{i=1}^{n} λ_i$$

This proves that for a square matrix over an algebraically closed field, the trace is the sum of the eigenvalues and the determinant is the product of the eigenvalues.

final: For a square matrix A over an algebraically closed field, tr(A) is the sum of its eigenvalues and det(A) is the product of its eigenvalues.
